choices.B: It enables engineers to continuously monitor all accounts and report on the services that are unprotected.
choices.C: It offers coverage for serverless functions on AWS only.
choices.A: It does not require any specific permissions to be granted before use.
choices.D: It helps engineers find all cloud-native services being used only on AWS.

choices.C: Up to N-2 versions of the Prisma Cloud Self-Hosted Console that the backup created
choices.B: The same version of the Prisma Cloud Self-Hosted Console that the backup created
choices.A: Any version of Prisma Cloud Self-Hosted Console
choices.D: The latest version of Prisma Cloud Self-Hosted Console

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
You can only restore Console from a backup file whose version exactly matches the current running version of Console.

https://docs.prismacloud.io/en/compute-edition/32/admin-guide/configure/disaster-recovery

I think B
You can only restore Console from a backup file whose version exactly matches the current running version of Console. Therefore, if the current running version of Console is v31.01.xxx, you cannot restore a backup whose version is v31.00.xxx.

https://docs.prismacloud.io/en/compute-edition/31/admin-guide/configure/disaster-recovery

C.
https://docs.prismacloud.io/en/compute-edition/31/admin-guide/upgrade/upgrade-process-self-hosted

Prisma Cloud Console is backward compatible with up to two (n-2) major releases back (including all minor versions) for the following:
All types of Defenders.

Twistcli/Jenkins plugin.

questions.question_text:
A Systems Engineer is the administrator of a self-hosted Prisma Cloud console. They upgraded the console to the latest version. However, after the upgrade, the console does not show all the policies configured. Before they upgraded the console, they created a backup manually and exported it to a local drive. Now they have to install a Prisma Cloud to restore from the backup that they manually created.

Which Prisma Cloud version can they can restore with the backup?
